linegroup.line: As fair as day.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Ay, as some days; but then no sun must shine.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: O that I had my wish!

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: And I had mine!

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: And I mine too, good Lord!

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Amen, so I had mine: is not that a good word?

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: I would forget her; but a fever she
Reigns in my blood and will remember'd be.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: A fever in your blood! why, then incision
Would let her out in saucers: sweet misprision!

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Once more I'll read the ode that I have writ.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Once more I'll mark how love can vary wit.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: On a day--alack the day!--
Love, whose month is ever May,
Spied a blossom passing fair
Playing in the wanton air:
Through the velvet leaves the wind,
All unseen, can passage find;
That the lover, sick to death,
Wish himself the heaven's breath.
Air, quoth he, thy cheeks may blow;
Air, would I might triumph so!
But, alack, my hand is sworn
Ne'er to pluck thee from thy thorn;
Vow, alack, for youth unmeet,
Youth so apt to pluck a sweet!
Do not call it sin in me,
That I am forsworn for thee;
Thou for whom Jove would swear
Juno but an Ethiope were;
And deny himself for Jove,
Turning mortal for thy love.
This will I send, and something else more plain,
That shall express my true love's fasting pain.
O, would the king, Biron, and Longaville,
Were lovers too! Ill, to example ill,
Would from my forehead wipe a perjured note;
For none offend where all alike do dote.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: Advancing Dumain, thy love is far from charity.
You may look pale, but I should blush, I know,
To be o'erheard and taken napping so.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Advancing Come, sir, you blush; as his your case is such;
You chide at him, offending twice as much;
You do not love Maria; Longaville
Did never sonnet for her sake compile,
Nor never lay his wreathed arms athwart
His loving bosom to keep down his heart.
I have been closely shrouded in this bush
And mark'd you both and for you both did blush:
I heard your guilty rhymes, observed your fashion,
Saw sighs reek from you, noted well your passion:
Ay me! says one; O Jove! the other cries;
One, her hairs were gold, crystal the other's eyes:
You would for paradise break faith, and troth;
And Jove, for your love, would infringe an oath.
What will Biron say when that he shall hear
Faith so infringed, which such zeal did swear?
How will he scorn! how will he spend his wit!
How will he triumph, leap and laugh at it!
For all the wealth that ever I did see,
I would not have him know so much by me.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Now step I forth to whip hypocrisy.
Ah, good my liege, I pray thee, pardon me!
Good heart, what grace hast thou, thus to reprove
These worms for loving, that art most in love?
Your eyes do make no coaches; in your tears
There is no certain princess that appears;
You'll not be perjured, 'tis a hateful thing;
Tush, none but minstrels like of sonneting!
But are you not ashamed? nay, are you not,
All three of you, to be thus much o'ershot?
You found his mote; the king your mote did see;
But I a beam do find in each of three.
O, what a scene of foolery have I seen,
Of sighs, of groans, of sorrow and of teen!
O me, with what strict patience have I sat,
To see a king transformed to a gnat!
To see great Hercules whipping a gig,
And profound Solomon to tune a jig,
And Nestor play at push-pin with the boys,
And critic Timon laugh at idle toys!
Where lies thy grief, O, tell me, good Dumain?
And gentle Longaville, where lies thy pain?
And where my liege's? all about the breast:
A caudle, ho!

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Too bitter is thy jest.
Are we betray'd thus to thy over-view?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Not you to me, but I betray'd by you:
I, that am honest; I, that hold it sin
To break the vow I am engaged in;
I am betray'd, by keeping company
With men like men of inconstancy.
When shall you see me write a thing in rhyme?
Or groan for love? or spend a minute's time
In pruning me? When shall you hear that I
Will praise a hand, a foot, a face, an eye,
A gait, a state, a brow, a breast, a waist,
A leg, a limb?

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Soft! whither away so fast?
A true man or a thief that gallops so?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: I post from love: good lover, let me go.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUENETTA
linegroup.line: God bless the king!

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: What present hast thou there?

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: Some certain treason.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: What makes treason here?

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: Nay, it makes nothing, sir.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: If it mar nothing neither,
The treason and you go in peace away together.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUENETTA
linegroup.line: I beseech your grace, let this letter be read:
Our parson misdoubts it; 'twas treason, he said.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Biron, read it over.
Where hadst thou it?

linegroup.speaker: JAQUENETTA
linegroup.line: Of Costard.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Where hadst thou it?

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: Of Dun Adramadio, Dun Adramadio.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: How now! what is in you? why dost thou tear it?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: A toy, my liege, a toy: your grace needs not fear it.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: It did move him to passion, and therefore let's hear it.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: It is Biron's writing, and here is his name.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: To COSTARD Ah, you whoreson loggerhead! you were
born to do me shame.
Guilty, my lord, guilty! I confess, I confess.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: What?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: That you three fools lack'd me fool to make up the mess:
He, he, and you, and you, my liege, and I,
Are pick-purses in love, and we deserve to die.
O, dismiss this audience, and I shall tell you more.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Now the number is even.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: True, true; we are four.
Will these turtles be gone?

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Hence, sirs; away!

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: Walk aside the true folk, and let the traitors stay.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Sweet lords, sweet lovers, O, let us embrace!
As true we are as flesh and blood can be:
The sea will ebb and flow, heaven show his face;
Young blood doth not obey an old decree:
We cannot cross the cause why we were born;
Therefore of all hands must we be forsworn.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: What, did these rent lines show some love of thine?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Did they, quoth you? Who sees the heavenly Rosaline,
That, like a rude and savage man of Inde,
At the first opening of the gorgeous east,
Bows not his vassal head and strucken blind
Kisses the base ground with obedient breast?
What peremptory eagle-sighted eye
Dares look upon the heaven of her brow,
That is not blinded by her majesty?

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: What zeal, what fury hath inspired thee now?
My love, her mistress, is a gracious moon;
She an attending star, scarce seen a light.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: My eyes are then no eyes, nor I Biron:
O, but for my love, day would turn to night!
Of all complexions the cull'd sovereignty
Do meet, as at a fair, in her fair cheek,
Where several worthies make one dignity,
Where nothing wants that want itself doth seek.
Lend me the flourish of all gentle tongues,--
Fie, painted rhetoric! O, she needs it not:
To things of sale a seller's praise belongs,
She passes praise; then praise too short doth blot.
A wither'd hermit, five-score winters worn,
Might shake off fifty, looking in her eye:
Beauty doth varnish age, as if new-born,
And gives the crutch the cradle's infancy:
O, 'tis the sun that maketh all things shine.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: By heaven, thy love is black as ebony.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Is ebony like her? O wood divine!
A wife of such wood were felicity.
O, who can give an oath? where is a book?
That I may swear beauty doth beauty lack,
If that she learn not of her eye to look:
No face is fair that is not full so black.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: O paradox! Black is the badge of hell,
The hue of dungeons and the suit of night;
And beauty's crest becomes the heavens well.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Devils soonest tempt, resembling spirits of light.
O, if in black my lady's brows be deck'd,
It mourns that painting and usurping hair
Should ravish doters with a false aspect;
And therefore is she born to make black fair.
Her favour turns the fashion of the days,
For native blood is counted painting now;
And therefore red, that would avoid dispraise,
Paints itself black, to imitate her brow.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: To look like her are chimney-sweepers black.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: And since her time are colliers counted bright.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: And Ethiopes of their sweet complexion crack.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Dark needs no candles now, for dark is light.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Your mistresses dare never come in rain,
For fear their colours should be wash'd away.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: 'Twere good, yours did; for, sir, to tell you plain,
I'll find a fairer face not wash'd to-day.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: I'll prove her fair, or talk till doomsday here.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: No devil will fright thee then so much as she.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: I never knew man hold vile stuff so dear.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: Look, here's thy love: my foot and her face see.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: O, if the streets were paved with thine eyes,
Her feet were much too dainty for such tread!

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: O, vile! then, as she goes, what upward lies
The street should see as she walk'd overhead.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: But what of this? are we not all in love?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Nothing so sure; and thereby all forsworn.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Then leave this chat; and, good Biron, now prove
Our loving lawful, and our faith not torn.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Ay, marry, there; some flattery for this evil.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: O, some authority how to proceed;
Some tricks, some quillets, how to cheat the devil.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Some salve for perjury.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: 'Tis more than need.
Have at you, then, affection's men at arms.
Consider what you first did swear unto,
To fast, to study, and to see no woman;
Flat treason 'gainst the kingly state of youth.
Say, can you fast? your stomachs are too young;
And abstinence engenders maladies.
And where that you have vow'd to study, lords,
In that each of you have forsworn his book,
Can you still dream and pore and thereon look?
For when would you, my lord, or you, or you,
Have found the ground of study's excellence
Without the beauty of a woman's face?
Why, universal plodding poisons up
The nimble spirits in the arteries,
As motion and long-during action tires
The sinewy vigour of the traveller.
Now, for not looking on a woman's face,
You have in that forsworn the use of eyes
And study too, the causer of your vow;
For where is any author in the world
Teaches such beauty as a woman's eye?
Learning is but an adjunct to ourself
And where we are our learning likewise is:
Then when ourselves we see in ladies' eyes,
Do we not likewise see our learning there?
O, we have made a vow to study, lords,
And in that vow we have forsworn our books.
For when would you, my liege, or you, or you,
In leaden contemplation have found out
Such fiery numbers as the prompting eyes
Of beauty's tutors have enrich'd you with?
Other slow arts entirely keep the brain;
And therefore, finding barren practisers,
Scarce show a harvest of their heavy toil:
But love, first learned in a lady's eyes,
Lives not alone immured in the brain;
But, with the motion of all elements,
Courses as swift as thought in every power,
And gives to every power a double power,
Above their functions and their offices.
It adds a precious seeing to the eye;
A lover's eyes will gaze an eagle blind;
A lover's ear will hear the lowest sound,
When the suspicious head of theft is stopp'd:
Love's feeling is more soft and sensible
Than are the tender horns of cockl'd snails;
Love's tongue proves dainty Bacchus gross in taste:
For valour, is not Love a Hercules,
Still climbing trees in the Hesperides?
Subtle as Sphinx; as sweet and musical
As bright Apollo's lute, strung with his hair:
And when Love speaks, the voice of all the gods
Makes heaven drowsy with the harmony.
Never durst poet touch a pen to write
Until his ink were temper'd with Love's sighs;
O, then his lines would ravish savage ears
And plant in tyrants mild humility.
From women's eyes this doctrine I derive:
They sparkle still the right Promethean fire;
They are the books, the arts, the academes,
That show, contain and nourish all the world:
Else none at all in ought proves excellent.
Then fools you were these women to forswear,
Or keeping what is sworn, you will prove fools.
For wisdom's sake, a word that all men love,
Or for love's sake, a word that loves all men,
Or for men's sake, the authors of these women,
Or women's sake, by whom we men are men,
Let us once lose our oaths to find ourselves,
Or else we lose ourselves to keep our oaths.
It is religion to be thus forsworn,
For charity itself fulfills the law,
And who can sever love from charity?

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Saint Cupid, then! and, soldiers, to the field!

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Advance your standards, and upon them, lords;
Pell-mell, down with them! but be first advised,
In conflict that you get the sun of them.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: Now to plain-dealing; lay these glozes by:
Shall we resolve to woo these girls of France?

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: And win them too: therefore let us devise
Some entertainment for them in their tents.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: First, from the park let us conduct them thither;
Then homeward every man attach the hand
Of his fair mistress: in the afternoon
We will with some strange pastime solace them,
Such as the shortness of the time can shape;
For revels, dances, masks and merry hours
Forerun fair Love, strewing her way with flowers.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Away, away! no time shall be omitted
That will betime, and may by us be fitted.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Allons! allons! Sow'd cockle reap'd no corn;
And justice always whirls in equal measure:
Light wenches may prove plagues to men forsworn;
If so, our copper buys no better treasure.

section.title: SCENE I. The same.
section.para: Enter HOLOFERNES, SIR NATHANIEL, and DULL

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Satis quod sufficit.

linegroup.speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
linegroup.line: I praise God for you, sir: your reasons at dinner
have been sharp and sententious; pleasant without
scurrility, witty without affection, audacious without
impudency, learned without opinion, and strange with-
out heresy. I did converse this quondam day with
a companion of the king's, who is intituled, nomi-
nated, or called, Don Adriano de Armado.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Novi hominem tanquam te: his humour is lofty, his
discourse peremptory, his tongue filed, his eye
ambitious, his gait majestical, and his general
behavior vain, ridiculous, and thrasonical. He is
too picked, too spruce, too affected, too odd, as it
were, too peregrinate, as I may call it.

linegroup.speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
linegroup.line: A most singular and choice epithet.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: He draweth out the thread of his verbosity finer
than the staple of his argument. I abhor such
fanatical phantasimes, such insociable and
point-devise companions; such rackers of
orthography, as to speak dout, fine, when he should
say doubt; det, when he should pronounce debt,--d,
e, b, t, not d, e, t: he clepeth a calf, cauf;
half, hauf; neighbour vocatur nebor; neigh
abbreviated ne. This is abhominable,--which he
would call abbominable: it insinuateth me of
insanie: anne intelligis, domine? to make frantic, lunatic.

linegroup.speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
linegroup.line: Laus Deo, bene intelligo.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Bon, bon, fort bon, Priscian! a little scratch'd,
'twill serve.

linegroup.speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
linegroup.line: Videsne quis venit?

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Video, et gaudeo.

section.para: Enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO, MOTH, and COSTARD

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Chirrah!

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Quare chirrah, not sirrah?

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Men of peace, well encountered.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Most military sir, salutation.

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Aside to COSTARD They have been at a great feast
of languages, and stolen the scraps.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: O, they have lived long on the alms-basket of words.
I marvel thy master hath not eaten thee for a word;
for thou art not so long by the head as
honorificabilitudinitatibus: thou art easier
swallowed than a flap-dragon.

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Peace! the peal begins.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: To HOLOFERNES Monsieur, are you not lettered?

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Yes, yes; he teaches boys the hornbook. What is a,
b, spelt backward, with the horn on his head?

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Ba, pueritia, with a horn added.

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Ba, most silly sheep with a horn. You hear his learning.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Quis, quis, thou consonant?

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: The third of the five vowels, if you repeat them; or
the fifth, if I.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: I will repeat them,--a, e, i,--

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: The sheep: the other two concludes it,--o, u.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Now, by the salt wave of the Mediterraneum, a sweet
touch, a quick venue of wit! snip, snap, quick and
home! it rejoiceth my intellect: true wit!

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Offered by a child to an old man; which is wit-old.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: What is the figure? what is the figure?

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Horns.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Thou disputest like an infant: go, whip thy gig.

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Lend me your horn to make one, and I will whip about
your infamy circum circa,--a gig of a cuckold's horn.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: An I had but one penny in the world, thou shouldst
have it to buy gingerbread: hold, there is the very
remuneration I had of thy master, thou halfpenny
purse of wit, thou pigeon-egg of discretion. O, an
the heavens were so pleased that thou wert but my
bastard, what a joyful father wouldst thou make me!
Go to; thou hast it ad dunghill, at the fingers'
ends, as they say.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: O, I smell false Latin; dunghill for unguem.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Arts-man, preambulate, we will be singled from the
barbarous. Do you not educate youth at the
charge-house on the top of the mountain?

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Or mons, the hill.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: At your sweet pleasure, for the mountain.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: I do, sans question.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Sir, it is the king's most sweet pleasure and
affection to congratulate the princess at her
pavilion in the posteriors of this day, which the
rude multitude call the afternoon.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: The posterior of the day, most generous sir, is
liable, congruent and measurable for the afternoon:
the word is well culled, chose, sweet and apt, I do
assure you, sir, I do assure.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Sir, the king is a noble gentleman, and my familiar,
I do assure ye, very good friend: for what is
inward between us, let it pass. I do beseech thee,
remember thy courtesy; I beseech thee, apparel thy
head: and among other important and most serious
designs, and of great import indeed, too, but let
that pass: for I must tell thee, it will please his
grace, by the world, sometime to lean upon my poor
shoulder, and with his royal finger, thus, dally
with my excrement, with my mustachio; but, sweet
heart, let that pass. By the world, I recount no
fable: some certain special honours it pleaseth his
greatness to impart to Armado, a soldier, a man of
travel, that hath seen the world; but let that pass.
The very all of all is,--but, sweet heart, I do
implore secrecy,--that the king would have me
present the princess, sweet chuck, with some
delightful ostentation, or show, or pageant, or
antique, or firework. Now, understanding that the
curate and your sweet self are good at such
eruptions and sudden breaking out of mirth, as it
were, I have acquainted you withal, to the end to
crave your assistance.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Sir, you shall present before her the Nine Worthies.
Sir, as concerning some entertainment of time, some
show in the posterior of this day, to be rendered by
our assistants, at the king's command, and this most
gallant, illustrate, and learned gentleman, before
the princess; I say none so fit as to present the
Nine Worthies.

linegroup.speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
linegroup.line: Where will you find men worthy enough to present them?

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Joshua, yourself; myself and this gallant gentleman,
Judas Maccabaeus; this swain, because of his great
limb or joint, shall pass Pompey the Great; the
page, Hercules,--

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Pardon, sir; error: he is not quantity enough for
that Worthy's thumb: he is not so big as the end of his club.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Shall I have audience? he shall present Hercules in
minority: his enter and exit shall be strangling a
snake; and I will have an apology for that purpose.

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: An excellent device! so, if any of the audience
hiss, you may cry 'Well done, Hercules! now thou
crushest the snake!' that is the way to make an
offence gracious, though few have the grace to do it.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: For the rest of the Worthies?--

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: I will play three myself.

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Thrice-worthy gentleman!

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Shall I tell you a thing?

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: We attend.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: We will have, if this fadge not, an antique. I
beseech you, follow.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Via, goodman Dull! thou hast spoken no word all this while.

linegroup.speaker: DULL
linegroup.line: Nor understood none neither, sir.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Allons! we will employ thee.

linegroup.speaker: DULL
linegroup.line: I'll make one in a dance, or so; or I will play
On the tabour to the Worthies, and let them dance the hay.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Most dull, honest Dull! To our sport, away!

section.title: SCENE II. The same.
section.para: Enter the PRINCESS, KATHARINE, ROSALINE, and MARIA

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Sweet hearts, we shall be rich ere we depart,
If fairings come thus plentifully in:
A lady wall'd about with diamonds!
Look you what I have from the loving king.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Madame, came nothing else along with that?

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Nothing but this! yes, as much love in rhyme
As would be cramm'd up in a sheet of paper,
Writ o' both sides the leaf, margent and all,
That he was fain to seal on Cupid's name.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: That was the way to make his godhead wax,
For he hath been five thousand years a boy.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Ay, and a shrewd unhappy gallows too.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: You'll ne'er be friends with him; a' kill'd your sister.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: He made her melancholy, sad, and heavy;
And so she died: had she been light, like you,
Of such a merry, nimble, stirring spirit,
She might ha' been a grandam ere she died:
And so may you; for a light heart lives long.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: What's your dark meaning, mouse, of this light word?

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: A light condition in a beauty dark.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: We need more light to find your meaning out.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: You'll mar the light by taking it in snuff;
Therefore I'll darkly end the argument.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Look what you do, you do it still i' the dark.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: So do not you, for you are a light wench.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Indeed I weigh not you, and therefore light.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: You weigh me not? O, that's you care not for me.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Great reason; for 'past cure is still past care.'

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Well bandied both; a set of wit well play'd.
But Rosaline, you have a favour too:
Who sent it? and what is it?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: I would you knew:
An if my face were but as fair as yours,
My favour were as great; be witness this.
Nay, I have verses too, I thank Biron:
The numbers true; and, were the numbering too,
I were the fairest goddess on the ground:
I am compared to twenty thousand fairs.
O, he hath drawn my picture in his letter!

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Any thing like?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Much in the letters; nothing in the praise.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Beauteous as ink; a good conclusion.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Fair as a text B in a copy-book.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: 'Ware pencils, ho! let me not die your debtor,
My red dominical, my golden letter:
O, that your face were not so full of O's!

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: A pox of that jest! and I beshrew all shrows.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: But, Katharine, what was sent to you from fair Dumain?

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Madam, this glove.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Did he not send you twain?

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Yes, madam, and moreover
Some thousand verses of a faithful lover,
A huge translation of hypocrisy,
Vilely compiled, profound simplicity.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: This and these pearls to me sent Longaville:
The letter is too long by half a mile.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: I think no less. Dost thou not wish in heart
The chain were longer and the letter short?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Ay, or I would these hands might never part.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: We are wise girls to mock our lovers so.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: They are worse fools to purchase mocking so.
That same Biron I'll torture ere I go:
O that I knew he were but in by the week!
How I would make him fawn and beg and seek
And wait the season and observe the times
And spend his prodigal wits in bootless rhymes
And shape his service wholly to my hests
And make him proud to make me proud that jests!
So perttaunt-like would I o'ersway his state
That he should be my fool and I his fate.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: None are so surely caught, when they are catch'd,
As wit turn'd fool: folly, in wisdom hatch'd,
Hath wisdom's warrant and the help of school
And wit's own grace to grace a learned fool.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: The blood of youth burns not with such excess
As gravity's revolt to wantonness.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Folly in fools bears not so strong a note
As foolery in the wise, when wit doth dote;
Since all the power thereof it doth apply
To prove, by wit, worth in simplicity.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Here comes Boyet, and mirth is in his face.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: O, I am stabb'd with laughter! Where's her grace?

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Thy news Boyet?

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Prepare, madam, prepare!
Arm, wenches, arm! encounters mounted are
Against your peace: Love doth approach disguised,
Armed in arguments; you'll be surprised:
Muster your wits; stand in your own defence;
Or hide your heads like cowards, and fly hence.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Saint Denis to Saint Cupid! What are they
That charge their breath against us? say, scout, say.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Under the cool shade of a sycamore
I thought to close mine eyes some half an hour;
When, lo! to interrupt my purposed rest,
Toward that shade I might behold addrest
The king and his companions: warily
I stole into a neighbour thicket by,
And overheard what you shall overhear,
That, by and by, disguised they will be here.
Their herald is a pretty knavish page,
That well by heart hath conn'd his embassage:
Action and accent did they teach him there;
'Thus must thou speak,' and 'thus thy body bear:'
And ever and anon they made a doubt
Presence majestical would put him out,
'For,' quoth the king, 'an angel shalt thou see;
Yet fear not thou, but speak audaciously.'
The boy replied, 'An angel is not evil;
I should have fear'd her had she been a devil.'
With that, all laugh'd and clapp'd him on the shoulder,
Making the bold wag by their praises bolder:
One rubb'd his elbow thus, and fleer'd and swore
A better speech was never spoke before;
Another, with his finger and his thumb,
Cried, 'Via! we will do't, come what will come;'
The third he caper'd, and cried, 'All goes well;'
The fourth turn'd on the toe, and down he fell.
With that, they all did tumble on the ground,
With such a zealous laughter, so profound,
That in this spleen ridiculous appears,
To cheque their folly, passion's solemn tears.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: But what, but what, come they to visit us?

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: They do, they do: and are apparell'd thus.
Like Muscovites or Russians, as I guess.
Their purpose is to parle, to court and dance;
And every one his love-feat will advance
Unto his several mistress, which they'll know
By favours several which they did bestow.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: And will they so? the gallants shall be task'd;
For, ladies, we shall every one be mask'd;
And not a man of them shall have the grace,
Despite of suit, to see a lady's face.
Hold, Rosaline, this favour thou shalt wear,
And then the king will court thee for his dear;
Hold, take thou this, my sweet, and give me thine,
So shall Biron take me for Rosaline.
And change your favours too; so shall your loves
Woo contrary, deceived by these removes.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Come on, then; wear the favours most in sight.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: But in this changing what is your intent?

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: The effect of my intent is to cross theirs:
They do it but in mocking merriment;
And mock for mock is only my intent.
Their several counsels they unbosom shall
To loves mistook, and so be mock'd withal
Upon the next occasion that we meet,
With visages displayed, to talk and greet.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: But shall we dance, if they desire to't?

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: No, to the death, we will not move a foot;
Nor to their penn'd speech render we no grace,
But while 'tis spoke each turn away her face.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Why, that contempt will kill the speaker's heart,
And quite divorce his memory from his part.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Therefore I do it; and I make no doubt
The rest will ne'er come in, if he be out
There's no such sport as sport by sport o'erthrown,
To make theirs ours and ours none but our own:
So shall we stay, mocking intended game,
And they, well mock'd, depart away with shame.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: The trumpet sounds: be mask'd; the maskers come.

section.para: Enter Blackamoors with music; MOTH; FERDINAND, BIRON, LONGAVILLE, and DUMAIN, in Russian habits, and masked

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: All hail, the richest beauties on the earth!--

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Beauties no richer than rich taffeta.

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: A holy parcel of the fairest dames.
linegroup.para: The Ladies turn their backs to him
linegroup.line: That ever turn'd their--backs--to mortal views!

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Aside to MOTH Their eyes, villain, their eyes!

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: That ever turn'd their eyes to mortal views!--Out--

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: True; out indeed.

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Out of your favours, heavenly spirits, vouchsafe
Not to behold--

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Aside to MOTH Once to behold, rogue.

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Once to behold with your sun-beamed eyes,
--with your sun-beamed eyes--

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: They will not answer to that epithet;
You were best call it 'daughter-beamed eyes.'

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: They do not mark me, and that brings me out.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Is this your perfectness? be gone, you rogue!

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: What would these strangers? know their minds, Boyet:
If they do speak our language, 'tis our will:
That some plain man recount their purposes
Know what they would.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: What would you with the princess?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: What would they, say they?

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Why, that they have; and bid them so be gone.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: She says, you have it, and you may be gone.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Say to her, we have measured many miles
To tread a measure with her on this grass.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: They say, that they have measured many a mile
To tread a measure with you on this grass.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: It is not so. Ask them how many inches
Is in one mile: if they have measured many,
The measure then of one is easily told.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: If to come hither you have measured miles,
And many miles, the princess bids you tell
How many inches doth fill up one mile.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Tell her, we measure them by weary steps.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: She hears herself.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: How many weary steps,
Of many weary miles you have o'ergone,
Are number'd in the travel of one mile?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: We number nothing that we spend for you:
Our duty is so rich, so infinite,
That we may do it still without accompt.
Vouchsafe to show the sunshine of your face,
That we, like savages, may worship it.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: My face is but a moon, and clouded too.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Blessed are clouds, to do as such clouds do!
Vouchsafe, bright moon, and these thy stars, to shine,
Those clouds removed, upon our watery eyne.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: O vain petitioner! beg a greater matter;
Thou now request'st but moonshine in the water.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Then, in our measure do but vouchsafe one change.
Thou bid'st me beg: this begging is not strange.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Play, music, then! Nay, you must do it soon.
Not yet! no dance! Thus change I like the moon.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Will you not dance? How come you thus estranged?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: You took the moon at full, but now she's changed.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Yet still she is the moon, and I the man.
The music plays; vouchsafe some motion to it.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Our ears vouchsafe it.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: But your legs should do it.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Since you are strangers and come here by chance,
We'll not be nice: take hands. We will not dance.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Why take we hands, then?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Only to part friends:
Curtsy, sweet hearts; and so the measure ends.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: More measure of this measure; be not nice.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: We can afford no more at such a price.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Prize you yourselves: what buys your company?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Your absence only.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: That can never be.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Then cannot we be bought: and so, adieu;
Twice to your visor, and half once to you.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: If you deny to dance, let's hold more chat.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: In private, then.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: I am best pleased with that.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: White-handed mistress, one sweet word with thee.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Honey, and milk, and sugar; there is three.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Nay then, two treys, and if you grow so nice,
Metheglin, wort, and malmsey: well run, dice!
There's half-a-dozen sweets.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Seventh sweet, adieu:
Since you can cog, I'll play no more with you.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: One word in secret.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Let it not be sweet.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Thou grievest my gall.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Gall! bitter.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Therefore meet.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Will you vouchsafe with me to change a word?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Name it.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Fair lady,--

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Say you so? Fair lord,--
Take that for your fair lady.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Please it you,
As much in private, and I'll bid adieu.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: What, was your vizard made without a tongue?

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: I know the reason, lady, why you ask.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: O for your reason! quickly, sir; I long.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: You have a double tongue within your mask,
And would afford my speechless vizard half.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Veal, quoth the Dutchman. Is not 'veal' a calf?

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: A calf, fair lady!

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: No, a fair lord calf.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: Let's part the word.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: No, I'll not be your half
Take all, and wean it; it may prove an ox.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: Look, how you butt yourself in these sharp mocks!
Will you give horns, chaste lady? do not so.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Then die a calf, before your horns do grow.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: One word in private with you, ere I die.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Bleat softly then; the butcher hears you cry.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: The tongues of mocking wenches are as keen
As is the razor's edge invisible,
Cutting a smaller hair than may be seen,
Above the sense of sense; so sensible
Seemeth their conference; their conceits have wings
Fleeter than arrows, bullets, wind, thought, swifter things.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Not one word more, my maids; break off, break off.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: By heaven, all dry-beaten with pure scoff!

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Farewell, mad wenches; you have simple wits.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Twenty adieus, my frozen Muscovits.
Are these the breed of wits so wonder'd at?

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Tapers they are, with your sweet breaths puff'd out.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Well-liking wits they have; gross, gross; fat, fat.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: O poverty in wit, kingly-poor flout!
Will they not, think you, hang themselves tonight?
Or ever, but in vizards, show their faces?
This pert Biron was out of countenance quite.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: O, they were all in lamentable cases!
The king was weeping-ripe for a good word.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Biron did swear himself out of all suit.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Dumain was at my service, and his sword:
No point, quoth I; my servant straight was mute.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Lord Longaville said, I came o'er his heart;
And trow you what he called me?

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Qualm, perhaps.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Yes, in good faith.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Go, sickness as thou art!

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Well, better wits have worn plain statute-caps.
But will you hear? the king is my love sworn.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: And quick Biron hath plighted faith to me.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: And Longaville was for my service born.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Dumain is mine, as sure as bark on tree.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Madam, and pretty mistresses, give ear:
Immediately they will again be here
In their own shapes; for it can never be
They will digest this harsh indignity.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Will they return?

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: They will, they will, God knows,
And leap for joy, though they are lame with blows:
Therefore change favours; and, when they repair,
Blow like sweet roses in this summer air.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: How blow? how blow? speak to be understood.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Fair ladies mask'd are roses in their bud;
Dismask'd, their damask sweet commixture shown,
Are angels vailing clouds, or roses blown.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Avaunt, perplexity! What shall we do,
If they return in their own shapes to woo?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Good madam, if by me you'll be advised,
Let's, mock them still, as well known as disguised:
Let us complain to them what fools were here,
Disguised like Muscovites, in shapeless gear;
And wonder what they were and to what end
Their shallow shows and prologue vilely penn'd
And their rough carriage so ridiculous,
Should be presented at our tent to us.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Ladies, withdraw: the gallants are at hand.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Whip to our tents, as roes run o'er land.

section.para: Exeunt PRINCESS, ROSALINE, KATHARINE, and MARIA
Re-enter FERDINAND, BIRON, LONGAVILLE, and DUMAIN, in their proper habits

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Fair sir, God save you! Where's the princess?

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Gone to her tent. Please it your majesty
Command me any service to her thither?

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: That she vouchsafe me audience for one word.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: I will; and so will she, I know, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: This fellow pecks up wit as pigeons pease,
And utters it again when God doth please:
He is wit's pedler, and retails his wares
At wakes and wassails, meetings, markets, fairs;
And we that sell by gross, the Lord doth know,
Have not the grace to grace it with such show.
This gallant pins the wenches on his sleeve;
Had he been Adam, he had tempted Eve;
A' can carve too, and lisp: why, this is he
That kiss'd his hand away in courtesy;
This is the ape of form, monsieur the nice,
That, when he plays at tables, chides the dice
In honourable terms: nay, he can sing
A mean most meanly; and in ushering
Mend him who can: the ladies call him sweet;
The stairs, as he treads on them, kiss his feet:
This is the flower that smiles on every one,
To show his teeth as white as whale's bone;
And consciences, that will not die in debt,
Pay him the due of honey-tongued Boyet.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: A blister on his sweet tongue, with my heart,
That put Armado's page out of his part!

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: See where it comes! Behavior, what wert thou
Till this madman show'd thee? and what art thou now?

section.para: Re-enter the PRINCESS, ushered by BOYET, ROSALINE, MARIA, and KATHARINE

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: All hail, sweet madam, and fair time of day!

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: 'Fair' in 'all hail' is foul, as I conceive.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Construe my speeches better, if you may.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Then wish me better; I will give you leave.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: We came to visit you, and purpose now
To lead you to our court; vouchsafe it then.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: This field shall hold me; and so hold your vow:
Nor God, nor I, delights in perjured men.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Rebuke me not for that which you provoke:
The virtue of your eye must break my oath.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: You nickname virtue; vice you should have spoke;
For virtue's office never breaks men's troth.
Now by my maiden honour, yet as pure
As the unsullied lily, I protest,
A world of torments though I should endure,
I would not yield to be your house's guest;
So much I hate a breaking cause to be
Of heavenly oaths, vow'd with integrity.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: O, you have lived in desolation here,
Unseen, unvisited, much to our shame.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Not so, my lord; it is not so, I swear;
We have had pastimes here and pleasant game:
A mess of Russians left us but of late.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: How, madam! Russians!

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Ay, in truth, my lord;
Trim gallants, full of courtship and of state.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Madam, speak true. It is not so, my lord:
My lady, to the manner of the days,
In courtesy gives undeserving praise.
We four indeed confronted were with four
In Russian habit: here they stay'd an hour,
And talk'd apace; and in that hour, my lord,
They did not bless us with one happy word.
I dare not call them fools; but this I think,
When they are thirsty, fools would fain have drink.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: This jest is dry to me. Fair gentle sweet,
Your wit makes wise things foolish: when we greet,
With eyes best seeing, heaven's fiery eye,
By light we lose light: your capacity
Is of that nature that to your huge store
Wise things seem foolish and rich things but poor.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: This proves you wise and rich, for in my eye,--

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: I am a fool, and full of poverty.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: But that you take what doth to you belong,
It were a fault to snatch words from my tongue.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: O, I am yours, and all that I possess!

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: All the fool mine?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: I cannot give you less.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Which of the vizards was it that you wore?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Where? when? what vizard? why demand you this?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: There, then, that vizard; that superfluous case
That hid the worse and show'd the better face.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: We are descried; they'll mock us now downright.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Let us confess and turn it to a jest.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Amazed, my lord? why looks your highness sad?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Help, hold his brows! he'll swoon! Why look you pale?
Sea-sick, I think, coming from Muscovy.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Thus pour the stars down plagues for perjury.
Can any face of brass hold longer out?
Here stand I lady, dart thy skill at me;
Bruise me with scorn, confound me with a flout;
Thrust thy sharp wit quite through my ignorance;
Cut me to pieces with thy keen conceit;
And I will wish thee never more to dance,
Nor never more in Russian habit wait.
O, never will I trust to speeches penn'd,
Nor to the motion of a schoolboy's tongue,
Nor never come in vizard to my friend,
Nor woo in rhyme, like a blind harper's song!
Taffeta phrases, silken terms precise,
Three-piled hyperboles, spruce affectation,
Figures pedantical; these summer-flies
Have blown me full of maggot ostentation:
I do forswear them; and I here protest,
By this white glove;--how white the hand, God knows!--
Henceforth my wooing mind shall be express'd
In russet yeas and honest kersey noes:
And, to begin, wench,--so God help me, la!--
My love to thee is sound, sans crack or flaw.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Sans sans, I pray you.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Yet I have a trick
Of the old rage: bear with me, I am sick;
I'll leave it by degrees. Soft, let us see:
Write, 'Lord have mercy on us' on those three;
They are infected; in their hearts it lies;
They have the plague, and caught it of your eyes;
These lords are visited; you are not free,
For the Lord's tokens on you do I see.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: No, they are free that gave these tokens to us.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Our states are forfeit: seek not to undo us.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: It is not so; for how can this be true,
That you stand forfeit, being those that sue?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Peace! for I will not have to do with you.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Nor shall not, if I do as I intend.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Speak for yourselves; my wit is at an end.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Teach us, sweet madam, for our rude transgression
Some fair excuse.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: The fairest is confession.
Were not you here but even now disguised?

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Madam, I was.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: And were you well advised?

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: I was, fair madam.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: When you then were here,
What did you whisper in your lady's ear?

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: That more than all the world I did respect her.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: When she shall challenge this, you will reject her.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Upon mine honour, no.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Peace, peace! forbear:
Your oath once broke, you force not to forswear.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Despise me, when I break this oath of mine.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: I will: and therefore keep it. Rosaline,
What did the Russian whisper in your ear?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Madam, he swore that he did hold me dear
As precious eyesight, and did value me
Above this world; adding thereto moreover
That he would wed me, or else die my lover.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: God give thee joy of him! the noble lord
Most honourably doth unhold his word.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: What mean you, madam? by my life, my troth,
I never swore this lady such an oath.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: By heaven, you did; and to confirm it plain,
You gave me this: but take it, sir, again.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: My faith and this the princess I did give:
I knew her by this jewel on her sleeve.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Pardon me, sir, this jewel did she wear;
And Lord Biron, I thank him, is my dear.
What, will you have me, or your pearl again?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Neither of either; I remit both twain.
I see the trick on't: here was a consent,
Knowing aforehand of our merriment,
To dash it like a Christmas comedy:
Some carry-tale, some please-man, some slight zany,
Some mumble-news, some trencher-knight, some Dick,
That smiles his cheek in years and knows the trick
To make my lady laugh when she's disposed,
Told our intents before; which once disclosed,
The ladies did change favours: and then we,
Following the signs, woo'd but the sign of she.
Now, to our perjury to add more terror,
We are again forsworn, in will and error.
Much upon this it is: and might not you
Forestall our sport, to make us thus untrue?
Do not you know my lady's foot by the squier,
And laugh upon the apple of her eye?
And stand between her back, sir, and the fire,
Holding a trencher, jesting merrily?
You put our page out: go, you are allow'd;
Die when you will, a smock shall be your shroud.
You leer upon me, do you? there's an eye
Wounds like a leaden sword.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Full merrily
Hath this brave manage, this career, been run.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Lo, he is tilting straight! Peace! I have done.
Welcome, pure wit! thou partest a fair fray.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: O Lord, sir, they would know
Whether the three Worthies shall come in or no.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: What, are there but three?

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: No, sir; but it is vara fine,
For every one pursents three.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: And three times thrice is nine.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: Not so, sir; under correction, sir; I hope it is not so.
You cannot beg us, sir, I can assure you, sir we know
what we know:
I hope, sir, three times thrice, sir,--

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Is not nine.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: Under correction, sir, we know whereuntil it doth amount.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: By Jove, I always took three threes for nine.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: O Lord, sir, it were pity you should get your living
by reckoning, sir.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: How much is it?

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: O Lord, sir, the parties themselves, the actors,
sir, will show whereuntil it doth amount: for mine
own part, I am, as they say, but to parfect one man
in one poor man, Pompion the Great, sir.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Art thou one of the Worthies?

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: It pleased them to think me worthy of Pompion the
Great: for mine own part, I know not the degree of
the Worthy, but I am to stand for him.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Go, bid them prepare.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: We will turn it finely off, sir; we will take
some care.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Biron, they will shame us: let them not approach.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: We are shame-proof, my lord: and tis some policy
To have one show worse than the king's and his company.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: I say they shall not come.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Nay, my good lord, let me o'errule you now:
That sport best pleases that doth least know how:
Where zeal strives to content, and the contents
Dies in the zeal of that which it presents:
Their form confounded makes most form in mirth,
When great things labouring perish in their birth.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: A right description of our sport, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Anointed, I implore so much expense of thy royal
sweet breath as will utter a brace of words.

section.para: Converses apart with FERDINAND, and delivers him a paper

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Doth this man serve God?

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Why ask you?

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: He speaks not like a man of God's making.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: That is all one, my fair, sweet, honey monarch; for,
I protest, the schoolmaster is exceeding
fantastical; too, too vain, too too vain: but we
will put it, as they say, to fortuna de la guerra.
I wish you the peace of mind, most royal couplement!

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Here is like to be a good presence of Worthies. He
presents Hector of Troy; the swain, Pompey the
Great; the parish curate, Alexander; Armado's page,
Hercules; the pedant, Judas Maccabaeus: And if
these four Worthies in their first show thrive,
These four will change habits, and present the other five.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: There is five in the first show.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: You are deceived; 'tis not so.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: The pedant, the braggart, the hedge-priest, the fool
and the boy:--
Abate throw at novum, and the whole world again
Cannot pick out five such, take each one in his vein.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: The ship is under sail, and here she comes amain.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: I Pompey am,--

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: You lie, you are not he.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: I Pompey am,--

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: With libbard's head on knee.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Well said, old mocker: I must needs be friends
with thee.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: I Pompey am, Pompey surnamed the Big--

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: The Great.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: It is, 'Great,' sir:--
Pompey surnamed the Great;
That oft in field, with targe and shield, did make
my foe to sweat:
And travelling along this coast, I here am come by chance,
And lay my arms before the legs of this sweet lass of France,
If your ladyship would say, 'Thanks, Pompey,' I had done.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Great thanks, great Pompey.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: 'Tis not so much worth; but I hope I was perfect: I
made a little fault in 'Great.'

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: My hat to a halfpenny, Pompey proves the best Worthy.

linegroup.speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
linegroup.line: When in the world I lived, I was the world's
commander;
By east, west, north, and south, I spread my
conquering might:
My scutcheon plain declares that I am Alisander,--

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Your nose says, no, you are not for it stands too right.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Your nose smells 'no' in this, most tender-smelling knight.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: The conqueror is dismay'd. Proceed, good Alexander.

linegroup.speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
linegroup.line: When in the world I lived, I was the world's
commander,--

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Most true, 'tis right; you were so, Alisander.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Pompey the Great,--

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: Your servant, and Costard.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Take away the conqueror, take away Alisander.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: To SIR NATHANIEL O, sir, you have overthrown
Alisander the conqueror! You will be scraped out of
the painted cloth for this: your lion, that holds
his poll-axe sitting on a close-stool, will be given
to Ajax: he will be the ninth Worthy. A conqueror,
and afeard to speak! run away for shame, Alisander.
There, an't shall please you; a foolish mild man; an
honest man, look you, and soon dashed. He is a
marvellous good neighbour, faith, and a very good
bowler: but, for Alisander,--alas, you see how
'tis,--a little o'erparted. But there are Worthies
a-coming will speak their mind in some other sort.

section.para: Enter HOLOFERNES, for Judas; and MOTH, for Hercules

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Great Hercules is presented by this imp,
Whose club kill'd Cerberus, that three-headed canis;
And when he was a babe, a child, a shrimp,
Thus did he strangle serpents in his manus.
Quoniam he seemeth in minority,
Ergo I come with this apology.
Keep some state in thy exit, and vanish.
Judas I am,--

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: A Judas!

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Not Iscariot, sir.
Judas I am, ycliped Maccabaeus.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Judas Maccabaeus clipt is plain Judas.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: A kissing traitor. How art thou proved Judas?

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Judas I am,--

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: The more shame for you, Judas.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: What mean you, sir?

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: To make Judas hang himself.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: Begin, sir; you are my elder.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Well followed: Judas was hanged on an elder.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: I will not be put out of countenance.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Because thou hast no face.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: What is this?

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: A cittern-head.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: The head of a bodkin.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: A Death's face in a ring.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: The face of an old Roman coin, scarce seen.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: The pommel of Caesar's falchion.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: The carved-bone face on a flask.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Saint George's half-cheek in a brooch.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Ay, and in a brooch of lead.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Ay, and worn in the cap of a tooth-drawer.
And now forward; for we have put thee in countenance.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: You have put me out of countenance.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: False; we have given thee faces.

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: But you have out-faced them all.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: An thou wert a lion, we would do so.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Therefore, as he is an ass, let him go.
And so adieu, sweet Jude! nay, why dost thou stay?

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: For the latter end of his name.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: For the ass to the Jude; give it him:--Jud-as, away!

linegroup.speaker: HOLOFERNES
linegroup.line: This is not generous, not gentle, not humble.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: A light for Monsieur Judas! it grows dark, he may stumble.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Alas, poor Maccabaeus, how hath he been baited!

section.para: Enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO, for Hector

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Hide thy head, Achilles: here comes Hector in arms.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Though my mocks come home by me, I will now be merry.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Hector was but a Troyan in respect of this.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: But is this Hector?

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: I think Hector was not so clean-timbered.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: His leg is too big for Hector's.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: More calf, certain.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: No; he is best endued in the small.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: This cannot be Hector.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: He's a god or a painter; for he makes faces.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty,
Gave Hector a gift,--

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: A gilt nutmeg.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: A lemon.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: Stuck with cloves.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: No, cloven.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Peace!--
The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty
Gave Hector a gift, the heir of Ilion;
A man so breathed, that certain he would fight; yea
From morn till night, out of his pavilion.
I am that flower,--

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: That mint.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: That columbine.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Sweet Lord Longaville, rein thy tongue.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: I must rather give it the rein, for it runs against Hector.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Ay, and Hector's a greyhound.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: The sweet war-man is dead and rotten; sweet chucks,
beat not the bones of the buried: when he breathed,
he was a man. But I will forward with my device.
Sweet royalty, bestow on me the sense of hearing.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Speak, brave Hector: we are much delighted.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: I do adore thy sweet grace's slipper.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Aside to DUMAIN Loves her by the foot,--

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Aside to BOYET He may not by the yard.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: This Hector far surmounted Hannibal,--

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: The party is gone, fellow Hector, she is gone; she
is two months on her way.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: What meanest thou?

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: Faith, unless you play the honest Troyan, the poor
wench is cast away: she's quick; the child brags in
her belly already: tis yours.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Dost thou infamonize me among potentates? thou shalt
die.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: Then shall Hector be whipped for Jaquenetta that is
quick by him and hanged for Pompey that is dead by
him.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Most rare Pompey!

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: Renowned Pompey!

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Greater than great, great, great, great Pompey!
Pompey the Huge!

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Hector trembles.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Pompey is moved. More Ates, more Ates! stir them
on! stir them on!

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Hector will challenge him.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Ay, if a' have no man's blood in's belly than will
sup a flea.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: By the north pole, I do challenge thee.

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: I will not fight with a pole, like a northern man:
I'll slash; I'll do it by the sword. I bepray you,
let me borrow my arms again.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Room for the incensed Worthies!

linegroup.speaker: COSTARD
linegroup.line: I'll do it in my shirt.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Most resolute Pompey!

linegroup.speaker: MOTH
linegroup.line: Master, let me take you a buttonhole lower. Do you
not see Pompey is uncasing for the combat? What mean
you? You will lose your reputation.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Gentlemen and soldiers, pardon me; I will not combat
in my shirt.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: You may not deny it: Pompey hath made the challenge.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Sweet bloods, I both may and will.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: What reason have you for't?

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: The naked truth of it is, I have no shirt; I go
woolward for penance.

linegroup.speaker: BOYET
linegroup.line: True, and it was enjoined him in Rome for want of
linen: since when, I'll be sworn, he wore none but
a dishclout of Jaquenetta's, and that a' wears next
his heart for a favour.

linegroup.speaker: MERCADE
linegroup.line: God save you, madam!

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Welcome, Mercade;
But that thou interrupt'st our merriment.

linegroup.speaker: MERCADE
linegroup.line: I am sorry, madam; for the news I bring
Is heavy in my tongue. The king your father--

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Dead, for my life!

linegroup.speaker: MERCADE
linegroup.line: Even so; my tale is told.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Worthies, away! the scene begins to cloud.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: For mine own part, I breathe free breath. I have
seen the day of wrong through the little hole of
discretion, and I will right myself like a soldier.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: How fares your majesty?

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Boyet, prepare; I will away tonight.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Madam, not so; I do beseech you, stay.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Prepare, I say. I thank you, gracious lords,
For all your fair endeavors; and entreat,
Out of a new-sad soul, that you vouchsafe
In your rich wisdom to excuse or hide
The liberal opposition of our spirits,
If over-boldly we have borne ourselves
In the converse of breath: your gentleness
Was guilty of it. Farewell worthy lord!
A heavy heart bears not a nimble tongue:
Excuse me so, coming too short of thanks
For my great suit so easily obtain'd.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: The extreme parts of time extremely forms
All causes to the purpose of his speed,
And often at his very loose decides
That which long process could not arbitrate:
And though the mourning brow of progeny
Forbid the smiling courtesy of love
The holy suit which fain it would convince,
Yet, since love's argument was first on foot,
Let not the cloud of sorrow justle it
From what it purposed; since, to wail friends lost
Is not by much so wholesome-profitable
As to rejoice at friends but newly found.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: I understand you not: my griefs are double.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Honest plain words best pierce the ear of grief;
And by these badges understand the king.
For your fair sakes have we neglected time,
Play'd foul play with our oaths: your beauty, ladies,
Hath much deform'd us, fashioning our humours
Even to the opposed end of our intents:
And what in us hath seem'd ridiculous,--
As love is full of unbefitting strains,
All wanton as a child, skipping and vain,
Form'd by the eye and therefore, like the eye,
Full of strange shapes, of habits and of forms,
Varying in subjects as the eye doth roll
To every varied object in his glance:
Which parti-coated presence of loose love
Put on by us, if, in your heavenly eyes,
Have misbecomed our oaths and gravities,
Those heavenly eyes, that look into these faults,
Suggested us to make. Therefore, ladies,
Our love being yours, the error that love makes
Is likewise yours: we to ourselves prove false,
By being once false for ever to be true
To those that make us both,--fair ladies, you:
And even that falsehood, in itself a sin,
Thus purifies itself and turns to grace.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: We have received your letters full of love;
Your favours, the ambassadors of love;
And, in our maiden council, rated them
At courtship, pleasant jest and courtesy,
As bombast and as lining to the time:
But more devout than this in our respects
Have we not been; and therefore met your loves
In their own fashion, like a merriment.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: Our letters, madam, show'd much more than jest.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: So did our looks.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: We did not quote them so.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Now, at the latest minute of the hour,
Grant us your loves.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: A time, methinks, too short
To make a world-without-end bargain in.
No, no, my lord, your grace is perjured much,
Full of dear guiltiness; and therefore this:
If for my love, as there is no such cause,
You will do aught, this shall you do for me:
Your oath I will not trust; but go with speed
To some forlorn and naked hermitage,
Remote from all the pleasures of the world;
There stay until the twelve celestial signs
Have brought about the annual reckoning.
If this austere insociable life
Change not your offer made in heat of blood;
If frosts and fasts, hard lodging and thin weeds
Nip not the gaudy blossoms of your love,
But that it bear this trial and last love;
Then, at the expiration of the year,
Come challenge me, challenge me by these deserts,
And, by this virgin palm now kissing thine
I will be thine; and till that instant shut
My woeful self up in a mourning house,
Raining the tears of lamentation
For the remembrance of my father's death.
If this thou do deny, let our hands part,
Neither entitled in the other's heart.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: If this, or more than this, I would deny,
To flatter up these powers of mine with rest,
The sudden hand of death close up mine eye!
Hence ever then my heart is in thy breast.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: [And what to me, my love? and what to me?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: You must be purged too, your sins are rack'd,
You are attaint with faults and perjury:
Therefore if you my favour mean to get,
A twelvemonth shall you spend, and never rest,
But seek the weary beds of people sick.]

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: But what to me, my love? but what to me? A wife?

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: A beard, fair health, and honesty;
With three-fold love I wish you all these three.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: O, shall I say, I thank you, gentle wife?

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Not so, my lord; a twelvemonth and a day
I'll mark no words that smooth-faced wooers say:
Come when the king doth to my lady come;
Then, if I have much love, I'll give you some.

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: I'll serve thee true and faithfully till then.

linegroup.speaker: KATHARINE
linegroup.line: Yet swear not, lest ye be forsworn again.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: What says Maria?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: At the twelvemonth's end
I'll change my black gown for a faithful friend.

linegroup.speaker: LONGAVILLE
linegroup.line: I'll stay with patience; but the time is long.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: The liker you; few taller are so young.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Studies my lady? mistress, look on me;
Behold the window of my heart, mine eye,
What humble suit attends thy answer there:
Impose some service on me for thy love.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Oft have I heard of you, my Lord Biron,
Before I saw you; and the world's large tongue
Proclaims you for a man replete with mocks,
Full of comparisons and wounding flouts,
Which you on all estates will execute
That lie within the mercy of your wit.
To weed this wormwood from your fruitful brain,
And therewithal to win me, if you please,
Without the which I am not to be won,
You shall this twelvemonth term from day to day
Visit the speechless sick and still converse
With groaning wretches; and your task shall be,
With all the fierce endeavor of your wit
To enforce the pained impotent to smile.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: To move wild laughter in the throat of death?
It cannot be; it is impossible:
Mirth cannot move a soul in agony.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALINE
linegroup.line: Why, that's the way to choke a gibing spirit,
Whose influence is begot of that loose grace
Which shallow laughing hearers give to fools:
A jest's prosperity lies in the ear
Of him that hears it, never in the tongue
Of him that makes it: then, if sickly ears,
Deaf'd with the clamours of their own dear groans,
Will hear your idle scorns, continue then,
And I will have you and that fault withal;
But if they will not, throw away that spirit,
And I shall find you empty of that fault,
Right joyful of your reformation.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: A twelvemonth! well; befall what will befall,
I'll jest a twelvemonth in an hospital.

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: To FERDINAND Ay, sweet my lord; and so I take my leave.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: No, madam; we will bring you on your way.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: Our wooing doth not end like an old play;
Jack hath not Jill: these ladies' courtesy
Might well have made our sport a comedy.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Come, sir, it wants a twelvemonth and a day,
And then 'twill end.

linegroup.speaker: BIRON
linegroup.line: That's too long for a play.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Sweet majesty, vouchsafe me,--

linegroup.speaker: PRINCESS
linegroup.line: Was not that Hector?

linegroup.speaker: DUMAIN
linegroup.line: The worthy knight of Troy.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: I will kiss thy royal finger, and take leave. I am
a votary; I have vowed to Jaquenetta to hold the
plough for her sweet love three years. But, most
esteemed greatness, will you hear the dialogue that
the two learned men have compiled in praise of the
owl and the cuckoo? It should have followed in the
end of our show.

linegroup.speaker: FERDINAND
linegroup.line: Call them forth quickly; we will do so.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: Holla! approach.
linegroup.para: Re-enter HOLOFERNES, SIR NATHANIEL, MOTH, COSTARD, and others
linegroup.line: This side is Hiems, Winter, this Ver, the Spring;
the one maintained by the owl, the other by the
cuckoo. Ver, begin.
When daisies pied and violets blue
And lady-smocks all silver-white
And cuckoo-buds of yellow hue
Do paint the meadows with delight,
The cuckoo then, on every tree,
Mocks married men; for thus sings he, Cuckoo;
Cuckoo, cuckoo: O word of fear,
Unpleasing to a married ear!
When shepherds pipe on oaten straws
And merry larks are ploughmen's clocks,
When turtles tread, and rooks, and daws,
And maidens bleach their summer smocks
The cuckoo then, on every tree,
Mocks married men; for thus sings he, Cuckoo;
Cuckoo, cuckoo: O word of fear,
Unpleasing to a married ear!
When icicles hang by the wall
And Dick the shepherd blows his nail
And Tom bears logs into the hall
And milk comes frozen home in pail,
When blood is nipp'd and ways be foul,
Then nightly sings the staring owl, Tu-whit;
Tu-who, a merry note,
While greasy Joan doth keel the pot.
When all aloud the wind doth blow
And coughing drowns the parson's saw
And birds sit brooding in the snow
And Marian's nose looks red and raw,
When roasted crabs hiss in the bowl,
Then nightly sings the staring owl, Tu-whit;
Tu-who, a merry note,
While greasy Joan doth keel the pot.

linegroup.speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
linegroup.line: The words of Mercury are harsh after the songs of
Apollo. You that way: we this way.
